data.question: Can you provide practice problems on multiplying two matrices?

docs.title: 674dcdb4b00b977d048c931b
docs.text: The admission tickets to the Singapore Zoo are $50 for an adult, $36 for a child, and $20 for a senior citizen. On a particular Tuesday, there were 212 adults, 251 children, and 15 senior citizens who visited the Singapore Zoo and on a particular Wednesday, there were 231 adults, 266 children, and 12 senior citizens who visited the Singapore Zoo. The number of visitors on the particular Tuesday and Wednesday can be represented by the matrix V = \begin{pmatrix} 212 & 251 & 15 \\ 231 & 266 & 12 \end{pmatrix}. \text{ (i) Write a } 3 \times 1 \text{ matrix, P, to represent the price of the admission tickets. (ii) Find the matrix } T = VP. \text{ (iii) Explain what each of the elements represents. (iv) Find the total amount collected from the sales of the tickets for the 2 days.}

docs.title: 674dcde1b00b977d048c9352
docs.text: Two outlets of a coffee chain sell three different types of coffee: espresso, flat white and mocha. The table shows the number of cups of each type of coffee sold on a particular day. Outlet A: Espresso 30, Flat White 30, Mocha 35; Outlet B: Espresso x, Flat White x + 2, Mocha 40. This information can be represented by the matrix \( P = \begin{pmatrix} 30 & 30 & 35 \\ x & x+2 & 40 \end{pmatrix} \). The coffee chain sells a cup of espresso at $2.50, a cup of flat white at $4 and a cup of mocha at $5.50. This information can be represented by the matrix \( Q = \begin{pmatrix} 2.5 \\ 4 \\ 5.5 \end{pmatrix} \). (a) Find, in terms of x, the matrix \( R = PQ \).

By using matrix multiplication, calculate the total amount of money the dance school earns for this 10-week block of sessions.

docs.text: Jane exchanged 500 Singapore dollars ($) into Thai baht (THB) when the exchange rate was $1 = 26.77 THB. She travelled to Thailand and spent 10,600 THB. On her return to Singapore, she exchanged the remaining Thai baht into dollars with the exchange rate $1 = 26.88 THB. Calculate the amount she received in dollars. Correct your answer to the nearest cent.

data.output:
A theme park has different ticket prices for weekdays and weekends. A weekday ticket costs $60 for adults, $40 for children, and $25 for seniors. On a weekday, there were 180 adults, 220 children, and 30 seniors who visited the park. On a weekend, ticket prices are $70 for adults, $45 for children, and $30 for seniors. On a weekend day, there were 210 adults, 260 children, and 50 seniors.

Represent the number of visitors as the matrix 
\[ V = \begin{pmatrix} 180 & 220 & 30 \\ 210 & 260 & 50 \end{pmatrix} \] \

(i) Write a \( 3 \times 1 \) matrix, \( P_W \), to represent the weekday ticket prices.

(ii) Write a \( 3 \times 1 \) matrix, \( P_{WE} \), to represent the weekend ticket prices.

(iii) Calculate the total revenue matrix \( R = VP_W + VP_{WE} \).

(iv) Explain what each element of the matrix \( R \) represents.

(v) Find the total amount collected from the sales of the tickets for both days.

The sales can be represented by the matrix \( S = \begin{pmatrix} 125 & 190 & 75 \\ 143 & 184 & 88 \end{pmatrix} \), where the first row represents sales on Monday and the second row on Tuesday. data.output: A school cafeteria offers three types of meals: Standard, Vegetarian, and Special Diet. On Monday, 40 standard meals, 50 vegetarian meals, and 20 special diet meals were served. On Tuesday, the numbers were 35, 55, and 25, respectively. The costs of each type of meal are $6, $8, and $10, respectively. Represent the number of meals served over the two days by matrix \( M \) and the costs by matrix \( C \). Then, calculate the total revenue generated over the two days by finding the matrix multiplication \( R = M \times C \). Describe what each element of the resulting matrix represents and find the total revenue.

data.output:
A concert sells tickets at three different prices: $60 for a front-row ticket, $45 for a middle-row ticket, and $30 for a back-row ticket. On Friday, there were 120 front-row, 150 middle-row, and 30 back-row tickets sold. On Saturday, 180 front-row, 120 middle-row, and 40 back-row tickets were sold. Represent the number of tickets sold on Friday and Saturday as a matrix \( N \), and the price of each type of ticket as a matrix \( M \).

(i) Write a \( 3\times 1 \) matrix, \( M \), to represent the price of each ticket.

(ii) Find the matrix \( R = NM \).

(iii) Explain what each element of matrix \( R \) represents.

(iv) Calculate the total amount collected from ticket sales for the two days.

data.output:
A movie theater sells three types of tickets: adult, youth, and senior. The prices for these tickets are $12, $8, and $6 respectively. On Saturday, three different theaters sold tickets as follows:

Theater 1 sold 150 adult, 200 youth, and 60 senior tickets.
Theater 2 sold 180 adult, 250 youth, and 80 senior tickets.
Theater 3 sold 160 adult, 230 youth, and 70 senior tickets.

This information can be represented by the matrix \( M = \begin{pmatrix} 150 & 200 & 60 \\ 180 & 250 & 80 \\ 160 & 230 & 70 \end{pmatrix} \).

(i) Write a \( 3 \times 1 \) matrix, \( P \), to represent the price of the tickets.

(ii) Find the matrix \( T = MP \).

(iii) Explain what each of the elements of the resulting matrix \( T \) represents.

(iv) Calculate the total revenue generated from all theaters on that Saturday.
